channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: AlphaFold3 — why did Nature publish it without its code?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01463-0

Criticism of our decision to publish AlphaFold3 raises important questions. We welcome readers’ views.
item.dc:title: AlphaFold3 — why did Nature publish it without its code?

item.title: Can mathematicians help to solve social-justice problems?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01494-7

Researchers discuss the triumphs and trials of using their craft to tackle society’s greatest challenges.
item.dc:title: Can mathematicians help to solve social-justice problems?
item.dc:creator: Rachel Crowell

item.title: Why role-playing games can spur climate action
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01466-x

Solving problems in a safe, collaborative environment can help us think out of the box and build empathy — crucial skills in a warming world.
item.dc:title: Why role-playing games can spur climate action
item.dc:creator: Sam Illingworth

item.title: China’s ChatGPT: what a boom in Chinese chatbots means for AI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01495-6

ChatGLM is one of hundreds of AI language models being developed for the Chinese language. It comes close to ChatGPT on many measures, say its creators.
item.dc:title: China’s ChatGPT: what a boom in Chinese chatbots means for AI
item.dc:creator: Celeste Biever

item.title: Internet use and teen mental health: it’s about more than just screen time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01489-4

Internet use and teen mental health: it’s about more than just screen time
item.dc:title: Internet use and teen mental health: it’s about more than just screen time
item.dc:creator: Linxiao Zhang

item.title: Trials that infected people with common colds can inform today’s COVID-19 challenge trials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01491-w

Trials that infected people with common colds can inform today’s COVID-19 challenge trials
item.dc:title: Trials that infected people with common colds can inform today’s COVID-19 challenge trials
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Ewbank

item.title: Mars rover mission will use pioneering nuclear power source
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01487-6

The radioactive unit will help to deliver Europe’s first Mars rover to the planet’s surface.
item.dc:title: Mars rover mission will use pioneering nuclear power source
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Social-media influence on teen mental health goes beyond just cause and effect
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01488-5

Social-media influence on teen mental health goes beyond just cause and effect
item.dc:title: Social-media influence on teen mental health goes beyond just cause and effect
item.dc:creator: Michael A. Spikes

item.title: Bad intercultural communication is hobbling academia — fix it for research equity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01490-x

Bad intercultural communication is hobbling academia — fix it for research equity
item.dc:title: Bad intercultural communication is hobbling academia — fix it for research equity
item.dc:creator: Shoumit Dey
Pooja Sharma

item.title: Save the forest to save the tiger — why vegetation conservation matters
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01368-y

The Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, emphasizes the importance of conserving wild plant species, plus a wonderstruck sky-watcher spots a brilliant meteor, in the weekly dip into Nature’s archive.
item.dc:title: Save the forest to save the tiger — why vegetation conservation matters

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: How psychology and neuroscience crack open the AI ‘black box’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01538-y

Researchers are borrowing approaches from psychology and neuroscience to find out how large language models ‘think’. Plus, self-driving super lab finds record-breaking laser material and AI-designed drugs get a reality check.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: How psychology and neuroscience crack open the AI ‘black box’
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Pay researchers to spot errors in published papers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01465-y

Borrowing the idea of ‘bug bounties’ from the technology industry could provide a systematic way to detect and correct the errors that litter the scientific literature.
item.dc:title: Pay researchers to spot errors in published papers
item.dc:creator: Malte Elson

item.title: First ‘bilingual’ brain-reading device decodes Spanish and English words
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01451-4

Artificial-intelligence system allows a man who cannot speak coherently to have a conversation in the language of his choice.
item.dc:title: First ‘bilingual’ brain-reading device decodes Spanish and English words
item.dc:creator: Amanda Heidt

item.title: Lab-grown sperm and eggs: ‘epigenetic’ reset in human cells paves the way
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01404-x

Technique wipes away tags on DNA that must be reprogrammed during development of reproductive cells.
item.dc:title: Lab-grown sperm and eggs: ‘epigenetic’ reset in human cells paves the way
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Harassment of scientists is surging — institutions aren’t sure how to help
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01468-9

As researchers increasingly face many kinds of attack over their work, there is debate about how to support and protect them.
item.dc:title: Harassment of scientists is surging — institutions aren’t sure how to help
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: A global pandemic treaty is in sight: don’t scupper it
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01464-z

Millions of people died of COVID-19 because the fundamental principle of equity between nations was ignored during the outbreak. That must not be allowed to happen again.
item.dc:title: A global pandemic treaty is in sight: don’t scupper it

item.title: Dumping, pillaging and slavery — why exploitation of the high seas must end
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01469-8

It’s time to sustainably manage the international ocean for marine and human life, says bold investigative book.
item.dc:title: Dumping, pillaging and slavery — why exploitation of the high seas must end
item.dc:creator: Diva Amon
Juliano Palacios Abrantes

item.title: Brazil’s plummeting graduate enrolments hint at declining interest in academic science careers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01504-8

The total number of individuals entering master’s and doctoral programmes dropped 12% between 2019 and 2022, reaching the lowest level in nearly a decade.
item.dc:title: Brazil’s plummeting graduate enrolments hint at declining interest in academic science careers
item.dc:creator: Rodrigo de Oliveira Andrade

item.title: How my research is putting blue crab on the menu in Croatia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01475-w

Neven Iveša investigates the invasive species in the Adriatic Sea, and works out how to lessen its impact.
item.dc:title: How my research is putting blue crab on the menu in Croatia
item.dc:creator: Jack Leeming

item.title: The origin of the cockroach: how a notorious pest conquered the world
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01454-1

Genomic analysis suggests the common kitchen vermin spread from Europe to the world. But it wasn't originally found in Europe.
item.dc:title: The origin of the cockroach: how a notorious pest conquered the world
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: How to set up your new lab space
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01479-6

An empty room can be intimidating. But with some thoughtful planning, you can create a thriving scientific community.
item.dc:title: How to set up your new lab space
item.dc:creator: Marissa Coppola
Jessica W. Tsai

item.title: China's Yangtze fish-rescue plan is a failure, study says
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01444-3

Researchers have debated the best management plan for highly endangered fish species since the 1980s.
item.dc:title: China's Yangtze fish-rescue plan is a failure, study says
item.dc:creator: Xiaoying You

item.title: Why the European Space Agency should join the US mission to Uranus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01470-1

Without international partnerships, NASA’s groundbreaking mission could fail to be ready in time for its optimal launch window.
item.dc:title: Why the European Space Agency should join the US mission to Uranus
item.dc:creator: Olivier Mousis
Robin M. Canup

item.title: Daily briefing: We must get to Uranus by 2050 — and Europe can help
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01497-4

How the European Space Agency can help boost a US mission to Uranus. Also, dams are hobbling ambitious conservation efforts for the Yangtze River and lessons from the first pig-organ transplants into humans.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: We must get to Uranus by 2050 — and Europe can help
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: How religious scientists balance work and faith
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01471-0

Researchers find ways to interweave faith and science, from discussing Ramadan fasts with colleagues to applying religious parables to lab work.
item.dc:title: How religious scientists balance work and faith
item.dc:creator: Anne Marie Conlon

item.title: Why babies in South Korea are suing the government
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01457-y

The first case in East Asia to challenge government climate policies will boost awareness of global warming and encourage further lawsuits in the region.
item.dc:title: Why babies in South Korea are suing the government
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: Infrastructure projects need to demonstrate a return on investment
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01462-1

Terms such as sustainability and inclusivity loom large in big infrastructure projects. But impact and value for money need measuring too, says Sinan Küfeoğlu.
item.dc:title: Infrastructure projects need to demonstrate a return on investment
item.dc:creator: Dom Byrne

item.title: DeepLabCut: the motion-tracking tool that went viral
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01474-x

Mackenzie and Alexander Mathis were still early in their careers when their software created a sensation. Now they’re using it to support other young scientists.
item.dc:title: DeepLabCut: the motion-tracking tool that went viral
item.dc:creator: Jyoti Madhusoodanan

Author Correction: Quantum control of a cat qubit with bit-flip times exceeding ten seconds
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Quantum control of a cat qubit with bit-flip times exceeding ten seconds

item.title: How cheesemaking could cook up an antidote for alcohol excess
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01398-6

A gel made from a milk protein reduces alcohol levels in the blood of intoxicated mice.
item.dc:title: How cheesemaking could cook up an antidote for alcohol excess

item.title: Reading between the lines: application essays predict university success
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01396-8

Applicants whose essays had broader ‘semantic content’ tended to achieve higher marks.
item.dc:title: Reading between the lines: application essays predict university success

item.title: Recycled sewage, public health and the memory of the world: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01450-5

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: Recycled sewage, public health and the memory of the world: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: Pig-organ transplants: what three human recipients have taught scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01453-2

As researchers mark the loss of the first living recipient of a pig kidney, they share what they’ve learnt about xenotransplantation.
item.dc:title: Pig-organ transplants: what three human recipients have taught scientists
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: mRNA therapy is safe for treating the inherited metabolic condition propionic acidaemia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01364-2

Propionic acidaemia is an inheirited metabolic condition caused by a lack of a liver enzyme, which leads to accumulation of toxic compounds. In a first-in-human trial, a therapeutic messenger RNA drug (mRNA-3927) led to restored enzyme activity, was well tolerated and showed a promising dose-dependent reduction of potentially life-threatening clinical events.
item.dc:title: mRNA therapy is safe for treating the inherited metabolic condition propionic acidaemia

item.title: Could bird flu in cows lead to a human outbreak? Slow response worries scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01416-7

The H5N1 virus is a long way from becoming adapted to humans, but limited testing and tracking mean we could miss danger signs.
item.dc:title: Could bird flu in cows lead to a human outbreak? Slow response worries scientists
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: Daniel Dennett obituary: ‘New atheism’ philosopher who sparked debate on consciousness
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01478-7

Cognitive scientist who boldly explored free will, the human mind and AI, and rejected the existence of God.
item.dc:title: Daniel Dennett obituary: ‘New atheism’ philosopher who sparked debate on consciousness
item.dc:creator: Liad Mudrik

item.title: Daily briefing: Long-lost branch of the Nile ran by the pyramids
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01485-8

Remains of an ancient branch of the Nile River hint at why Egyptians chose to build at Giza. Plus, how a ‘tactical sacrifice’ can save a building from collapse the our pick of the five best science books to read this week.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Long-lost branch of the Nile ran by the pyramids
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: US halts funding to controversial virus-hunting group: what researchers think
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01460-3

Some scientists think the decision regarding EcoHealth Alliance is fair; others say it might negatively affect virus surveillance.
item.dc:title: US halts funding to controversial virus-hunting group: what researchers think
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Found at last: long-lost branch of the Nile that ran by the pyramids
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01449-y

Geological survey reveals the remains of a major waterway that ancient Egyptian builders could have used to transport materials.
item.dc:title: Found at last: long-lost branch of the Nile that ran by the pyramids
item.dc:creator: Freda Kreier

item.title: Daily briefing: ‘Quantum internet’ demonstrated in three cities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01473-y

Three research teams each created quantum-entangled states over several kilometres of existing optical fibres in real urban areas. Plus, lizard-inspired buildings could save lives and linguists are re-examining the idea that people are shaped by their native language.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: ‘Quantum internet’ demonstrated in three cities
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Gut microbes linked to fatty diet drive tumour growth
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01443-4

Scientists know there is a link between obesity and some cancers. A study in mice and people suggests why that might be.
item.dc:title: Gut microbes linked to fatty diet drive tumour growth
item.dc:creator: Gillian Dohrn

item.title: Imprinting of serum neutralizing antibodies by Wuhan-1 mRNA vaccines
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07539-1

Imprinting of serum neutralizing antibodies by Wuhan-1 mRNA vaccines
item.dc:title: Imprinting of serum neutralizing antibodies by Wuhan-1 mRNA vaccines

item.title: Organoids merge to model the blood–brain barrier
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01397-7

Combining a brain organoid with a blood-vessel organoid yields a system similar to a protective mesh in the brain.
item.dc:title: Organoids merge to model the blood–brain barrier

item.title: Controlled failure: The building designed to limit catastrophe
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01384-y

New design - inspired by lizard tails - could save lives by isolating collapsing sections of damaged buildings
item.dc:title: Controlled failure: The building designed to limit catastrophe
item.dc:creator: Dan Fox

item.title: Evolution of a novel adrenal cell type that promotes parental care
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07423-y

The adrenal gland of the oldfield mouse (Peromyscus polionotus) has a recently evolved cell type that promotes monogamous-typical parenting behaviour and is not present in closely related species.
item.dc:title: Evolution of a novel adrenal cell type that promotes parental care
item.dc:creator: Natalie Niepoth

item.title: Suppressed thermal transport in silicon nanoribbons by inhomogeneous strain
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07390-4

We report on a method for inducing uncontaminated and precise inhomogeneous strain in nanoscale silicon ribbons and its use for determining physical effects in these strained materials, in particular, an increase in the range and control of thermal conductivity.
item.dc:title: Suppressed thermal transport in silicon nanoribbons by inhomogeneous strain

item.title: The rise of baobab trees in Madagascar
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07447-4

We carried out genomic and ecological analyses of all eight extant baobab species, providing insights into their evolutionary history and recommendations for conservation efforts.
item.dc:title: The rise of baobab trees in Madagascar

Sheng-Wei Wang

item.title: Arresting failure propagation in buildings through collapse isolation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07268-5

A design approach arrests collapse propagation in buildings after major initial failures by ensuring that specific elements fail before the failure of the most important components for global stability.
item.dc:title: Arresting failure propagation in buildings through collapse isolation
item.dc:creator: Nirvan Makoond
Andri Setiawan
Manuel Buitrago
Jose M. Adam

item.title: Dispersion-assisted high-dimensional photodetector
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07398-w

By combining spatial and frequency dispersive thin-film interfaces with deep residual learning, a miniature photodetector allowing the acquisition of high-dimensional information on light in a single-shot fashion is described.
item.dc:title: Dispersion-assisted high-dimensional photodetector
item.dc:creator: Yandong Fan
Weian Huang
Fei Zhu
Xingsi Liu
Chunqi Jin
Chenzi Guo
Yang An
Yuri Kivshar
Cheng-Wei Qiu
Wei Li

item.title: GLP-1-directed NMDA receptor antagonism for obesity treatment
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07419-8

Unimolecular integration of NMDA receptor antagonism with GLP-1 receptor agonism effectively reverses obesity, hyperglycaemia and dyslipidaemia in rodent models of metabolic disease.
item.dc:title: GLP-1-directed NMDA receptor antagonism for obesity treatment
item.dc:creator: Jonas Petersen

item.title: Photocatalytic doping of organic semiconductors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07400-5

A previously undescribed photocatalytic approach enables the effective p-type and n-type doping of organic semiconductors at room temperature using only widely available weak dopants such as oxygen and triethylamine.
item.dc:title: Photocatalytic doping of organic semiconductors
item.dc:creator: Wenlong Jin

item.title: The temperature sensor TWA1 is required for thermotolerance in Arabidopsis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07424-x

TWA1 is a temperature-sensing transcriptional co-regulator that is needed for basal and acquired thermotolerance in Arabidopsis thaliana.
item.dc:title: The temperature sensor TWA1 is required for thermotolerance in Arabidopsis
item.dc:creator: Lisa Bohn
Jin Huang
Susan Weidig
Zhenyu Yang
Christoph Heidersberger
Bernard Genty
Pascal Falter-Braun
Alexander Christmann
Erwin Grill

item.title: Temporal multiplexing of perception and memory codes in IT cortex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07349-5

We examined how familiar faces are encoded in inferotemporal, perirhinal and temporal pole face patches, and found that relative response magnitude to familiar versus unfamiliar faces was not a stable indicator of familiarity in any patch.
item.dc:title: Temporal multiplexing of perception and memory codes in IT cortex
item.dc:creator: Liang She
Marcus K. Benna
Yuelin Shi
Stefano Fusi
Doris Y. Tsao

item.title: Superconducting diode effect and interference patterns in kagome CsV<sub>3</sub>Sb<sub>5</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07431-y

We observe the superconducting diode effect and interference patterns in CsV3Sb5, implying a time-reversal symmetry-breaking superconducting order in kagome superconductors.
item.dc:title: Superconducting diode effect and interference patterns in kagome CsV<sub>3</sub>Sb<sub>5</sub>

Yugui Yao
Congjun Wu
Xiao Lin

item.title: Physiological temperature drives TRPM4 ligand recognition and gating
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07436-7

A temperature-dependent Ca2+-binding site in the intracellular domain of TRPM4 is essential for TRPM4 function in physiological contexts.
item.dc:title: Physiological temperature drives TRPM4 ligand recognition and gating
item.dc:creator: Jinhong Hu
Sung Jin Park
Tyler Walter
Ian J. Orozco

Wei Lü

item.title: Entanglement of nanophotonic quantum memory nodes in a telecom network
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07252-z

Entanglement of two nanophotonic quantum network nodes is demonstrated through 40  km spools of low-loss fibre and a 35-km long fibre loop deployed in the Boston area urban environment.
item.dc:title: Entanglement of nanophotonic quantum memory nodes in a telecom network

item.title: Engineered CD47 protects T cells for enhanced antitumour immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07443-8

Combination of TCR or CAR T cells expressing the engineered CD47 variant 47E with anti-CD47 antibody therapy results in synergistic antitumour efficacy due to T cell resistance to clearance by macrophages, while maintaining macrophage recruitment into the tumour microenvironment.
item.dc:title: Engineered CD47 protects T cells for enhanced antitumour immunity

item.title: Wavefunction matching for solving quantum many-body problems
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07422-z

An approach called wavefunction matching transforms particle interactions so that their wavefunctions match those of easily computable interactions, to allow for calculations of quantum many-body systems that would otherwise be difficult or impossible.
item.dc:title: Wavefunction matching for solving quantum many-body problems
item.dc:creator: Serdar Elhatisari

item.title: One-third of Southern Ocean productivity is supported by dust deposition
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07366-4

Nitrate observations over 11 years from autonomous biogeochemical ocean profiling combined with a Southern Hemisphere dust simulation find that iron supplied by dust supports about 30% of Southern Ocean productivity.
item.dc:title: One-third of Southern Ocean productivity is supported by dust deposition
item.dc:creator: Jakob Weis
Zanna Chase
Christina Schallenberg
Peter G. Strutton
Andrew R. Bowie
Sonya L. Fiddes

item.title: Decoding the interplay between genetic and non-genetic drivers of metastasis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07302-6

This Review discusses the importance of genetic and non-genetic reprogramming events during the metastatic cascade.
item.dc:title: Decoding the interplay between genetic and non-genetic drivers of metastasis
item.dc:creator: Panagiotis Karras
James R. M. Black
Nicholas McGranahan
Jean-Christophe Marine

item.title: A renewably sourced, circular photopolymer resin for additive manufacturing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07399-9

A photopolymer platform derived from renewable lipoates can be 3D-printed into high-resolution parts, which possess properties comparable to some commercial acrylic resins, and then recycled to produce a re-printable resin.
item.dc:title: A renewably sourced, circular photopolymer resin for additive manufacturing
item.dc:creator: Thiago O. Machado
Connor J. Stubbs
Viviane Chiaradia
Maher A. Alraddadi
Arianna Brandolese
Joshua C. Worch
Andrew P. Dove

item.title: Volatile working memory representations crystallize with practice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07425-w

Delay- and choice-related activities that are essential for working-memory performance drift during learning and stabilize only after several days of expert performance.
item.dc:title: Volatile working memory representations crystallize with practice
item.dc:creator: Arash Bellafard
Ghazal Namvar
Jonathan C. Kao
Alipasha Vaziri
Peyman Golshani

item.title: Release of a ubiquitin brake activates OsCERK1-triggered immunity in rice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07418-9

The ubiquitin E3 ligase OsCIE1 acts as a brake to inhibit OsCERK1 during homeostasis; this brake is released after chitin stimulation.
item.dc:title: Release of a ubiquitin brake activates OsCERK1-triggered immunity in rice

item.title: Dimerization and antidepressant recognition at noradrenaline transporter
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07437-6

Cryo-electron microscopy structures of the noradrenaline transporter in the apo state, bound to noradrenaline and bound to various antidepressants shed light on the substrate transport, molecular recognition and dimeric architecture of this protein.
item.dc:title: Dimerization and antidepressant recognition at noradrenaline transporter

item.title: Creation of memory–memory entanglement in a metropolitan quantum network
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07308-0

A metropolitan-area quantum network based on the generation of pairwise entanglement is formed by three atomic quantum memories connected to a central photonic server.
item.dc:title: Creation of memory–memory entanglement in a metropolitan quantum network

item.title: Daily briefing: How AI could help mathematicians achieve ‘moments of divine inspiration’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01458-x

Mathematical conjectures could be the ideal testing ground for AI-assisted discovery. Plus, why humans are so good at running and how to kill ‘zombie’ cells that make us age.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: How AI could help mathematicians achieve ‘moments of divine inspiration’
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: I’m worried I’ve been contacted by a predatory publisher — how do I find out?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01437-2

Researchers frequently receive invitations to publish in journals that they might not have heard of. Nature asked two scientists how they would check whether a publication is legitimate.
item.dc:title: I’m worried I’ve been contacted by a predatory publisher — how do I find out?
item.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

item.title: Dual-action obesity drug rewires brain circuits for appetite
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01352-6

A two-in-one drug that modulates neural pathways involved in appetite and reward might prove to be more effective and longer lasting than current weight-loss drugs on the market.
item.dc:title: Dual-action obesity drug rewires brain circuits for appetite
item.dc:creator: Tyler M. Cook
Darleen Sandoval
